case_vignette:
A 13-month-old toddler with spreading eczema on his trunk and arms is brought in by his mother. She is applying moisturizer and a cortisone cream. However, 2 days earlier, a wound appeared on his left hand that appears to be infected. Since then, more areas of raw, oozing skin have developed. Examination reveals lichenified scaling plaques scattered on the trunk and posterior knees and arms, and his left arm has monomorphic crusted vesicles and ulcerations on an erythematous base. The patient is afebrile, but the mother reports that he has been irritable and has had difficulty sleeping. The patient's mother is concerned that the eczema is worsening and that the infection is not responding to treatment.

A 13-month-old toddler with spreading eczema on the trunk and arms is brought in by a parent. The parent is applying moisturizer and a cortisone cream. However, 2 days earlier, a wound appeared on the left hand that appears to be infected. Since then, more areas of raw, oozing skin have developed. Examination reveals lichenified scaling plaques scattered on the trunk and posterior knees and arms, and the left arm has monomorphic crusted vesicles and ulcerations on an erythematous base. The patient is afebrile, but the parent reports that the child has been irritable and has had difficulty sleeping. The parent is concerned that the eczema is worsening and that the infection is not responding to treatment.
Note: I removed the word "mother" and replaced it with "parent" to make the text more inclusive. I also removed the word "his" and replaced it with "the" to make the text more neutral. question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

I have spreading eczema on my trunk and arms, and a wound on my left hand that seems infected. There are also more areas of my skin that are raw and oozing. I've been feeling irritable and have had difficulty sleeping.
Have you had any fever or chills along with these symptoms?
No, I have not had any fever.
How long have you had these symptoms, and have they worsened over time?
I've had the spreading eczema for a while, but the wound on my left hand and the worsening of my skin started about 2 days ago.
Do you have any known allergies or have you started using any new skincare products, detergents, or been exposed to any chemicals or irritants recently?
The information about any allergies or recent exposures to new products or irritants is not available.
Have you tried any medications or treatments for your symptoms so far? If yes, what were they?
Yes, I have been using moisturizer and a cortisone cream.
Do you have a history of atopic dermatitis (eczema) or other skin diseases in your family?
The information about family history of atopic dermatitis or other skin diseases is not available.
Is the wound on your hand deep or superficial, and was it caused by an injury?
The wound on my hand appears to be infected, but the details about the depth of the wound or its cause are not specified.
Final Diagnosis: Eczema herpeticum.
